node.title: Senior cleric linked to terror network behind the Bali nightclub bombings charged over alleged sham charity
node.alt: The bomb blast scene in Kuta several days after the bomb blasts.
node.description: The charity used the cover of social and educational motives to collect funds and divert some of them toÂ terror group Jemaah Islamiyah, which is regrouping after its spiritual leader Abu Bakar Bashir was released from prison this year.
node.content:
["A senior Indonesian cleric has been charged over allegations he raised funds for the Al Qaeda-linked terror network behind the 2002 Bali nightclub bombings and other attacks.", "Ahmad Zain An-Najah, a member of top Islamic organisation the Indonesian Ulema Council, and two associates have been charged with setting up a charity organisation that diverted money to terror group Jemaah Islamiyah\u00a0[JI].", "The organisation operated in cities on Sumatra and Java islands, including Jakarta, he said.", "The cleric worked in the council's fatwa division, which is in charge of issuing religious edicts, police said.", "Terror groups in Indonesia, which has suffered a string of attacks since the 2002 Bali attacks, have used charities as a cover to raise funds to finance their operations, authorities have said previously.", "In August, police arrested dozens of suspected extremists linked to JI and said the group had been planning a fresh attack during Indonesia's independence day celebrations.", "
Terror group rebuilding after spiritual leader leaves jail
", "", "
Abu Bakar Bashir has continued to deny involvement in the Bali bombings.(ABC News: David Lipson)
", "JI was nearly dismantled by authorities after\u00a0bombs ripped through nightclubs on the holiday island of Bali, in the district of Kuta in October 2002, killing 202 people, including 88 Australians.", "At around 11:00pm local time on October 12, bombs went off at the Sari Club and Paddy's Bar, explosions that Australian investigators later concluded was \"designed to maximise the number of deaths\".", "The attacks left 209 others injured and remain the single largest loss of Australian life from an act of terror, as well as Indonesia's deadliest terror attack.", "But the organisation has been rebuilding and its spiritual leader Abu Bakar Bashir was released from prison this year after serving time on terror-related charges.", "After being in and out of jail for a range of different terrorism offences, Bashir was given a 15-year jail sentence in 2011 for supporting militant training camps in Indonesia's Aceh province.", "The outlawed JI has ties with Al Qaeda and has been implicated in other attacks over the past two decades.", "It has also sent jihadists to fight in Syria and Iraq, authorities have said.", "Indonesia is home to dozens of extremist organisations, including some loyal to the Islamic State [IS] group.", "In March, an IS-inspired Indonesian couple blew themselves up at a church in Makassar on Sulawesi island, killing themselves and injuring dozens.", "ABC/Wires"]
